temperature.title: Temperature
temperature.content:
Listeria monocytogenes are psychrotrophic bacteria; they can grow at a large range of temperature, from -2°C to 45°C, although their optimal range is 30-37°C. One of their characteristics is that they can survive at very low temperature, until -18°C.
L. monocytogenes are sensitive to heat. For example, at 65°C, the population is divided by 10 in 0.2 to 2 min in skimmed milk.

oxygen.title: Oxygen
oxygen.content: Listeria monocytogenes are facultatively anaerobic and microaerophilic organisms. That means that they are able to grow in presence or absence of O2, as for example under vacuum or modified gas atmosphere.

ph.title: pH
ph.content:
Listeria monocytogenes can sustain wide range of pH from 3.3 to 9.6 and can grow optimally at pH 7.0.
The regulation considers products with pH ≤ 4,4 or products with pH ≤ 5,0 and aw ≤ 0,94 as unable to support the growth of L. monocytogenes.

humidity.title: Water
humidity.content: Listeria monocytogenes can grow with a water activity (aw) > 0.92 but can survive for lower aw. The regulation considers products with aw ≤ 0,92 and products with pH ≤ 5,0 and aw ≤ 0,94 as unable to support the growth of L. monocytogenes.

salinity.title: Salinity
salinity.content: Listeria monocytogenes are able to survive in high salinity concentration (> 20.0%). Their optimal growth is with 12% of sodium chloride.
